subs.text: July 8

A couple of times recently, I made a mild joke that had women I didn’t know laugh their asses off. One was about when I didn’t have legroom at Massey Hall and I joked that it was just the way I liked it. Today I said to one, “Don’t follow us, we don’t know where we’re going.”
subs.rawText: A couple of times recently, I made a mild joke that had women I didn’t know laugh their asses off. One was about when I didn’t have legroom at Massey Hall and I joked that it was just the way I liked it. Today I said to one, “Don’t follow us, we don’t know where we’re going.”

subs.text: They were intended as mildly funny jokes, just to relieve the awkwardness (awkwardity?) of the situation, not for them to bust out laughing.
subs.rawText: They were intended as mildly funny jokes, just to relieve the awkwardness (awkwardity?) of the situation, not for them to bust out laughing.

subs.text: Maybe they were high? I can’t tell if someone is high just by looking at them.
subs.rawText: Maybe they were high? I can’t tell if someone is high just by looking at them.

subs.text: “Only go up the CN Tower once in your life,” said the guy who’s now been up it 3 times in his life.
subs.rawText: “Only go up the CN Tower once in your life,” said the guy who’s now been up it 3 times in his life.

subs.text: I guess the deal’s off, so I’m sticking around here.

subs.text: New series: My Pet Peeves.
subs.rawText: New series: My Pet Peeves.

subs.text: Pet peeve: When people write words like “anxiousness” and “briefness” when there’s beautiful words like “anxiety” and “brevity” just looking at them like in the distracted boyfriend meme.
subs.rawText: Pet peeve: When people write words like “anxiousness” and “briefness” when there’s beautiful words like “anxiety” and “brevity” just looking at them like in the distracted boyfriend meme.

subs.text: Saying them out loud, fine, I’ll give you a pass. But when writing them out you have a chance to press the backspace key.
subs.rawText: Saying them out loud, fine, I’ll give you a pass. But when writing them out you have a chance to press the backspace key.

subs.text: Pet peeve: People talking while I’m walking in front of them. I don’t have an explanation for it, it just gets on my nerves. I let people pass me when that happens.
subs.rawText: Pet peeve: People talking while I’m walking in front of them. I don’t have an explanation for it, it just gets on my nerves. I let people pass me when that happens.

subs.text: I took at call at work today, and the customer was looking for someone named Richard who wasn’t me, so I thought he was asking for the other Richard in my department, but it was actually for someone we call Rich, not in my department. Now I can’t stop thinking about Mrs. Bucket. [link]
subs.rawText: I took at call at work today, and the customer was looking for someone named Richard who wasn’t me, so I thought he was asking for the other Richard in my department, but it was actually for someone we call Rich, not in my department. Now I can’t stop thinking about Mrs. Bucket. https://t.co/gdmuUOUArE

subs.text: Today was Tall Women Day in Toronto, evidently. #TallWomenDay
subs.rawText: Today was Tall Women Day in Toronto, evidently. #TallWomenDay

subs.text: Looks like I was out of town for Tall Women Day last year. That’s why I missed it. #TallWomenDay
subs.rawText: Looks like I was out of town for Tall Women Day last year. That’s why I missed it. #TallWomenDay

subs.text: It’s weird that Tall Women Day isn’t on a predictable day. It was in September in 2020, November in 2021, and July in 2022. Huh? #TallWomenDay
subs.rawText: It’s weird that Tall Women Day isn’t on a predictable day. It was in September in 2020, November in 2021, and July in 2022. Huh? #TallWomenDay

subs.text: You know what’s irritating? News anchors talking over the first few words of a speech they are about to cover. You know what they could do instead, and very few people would care? Delay the feed of the speech ever so slightly so that we get to hear everything.
subs.rawText: You know what’s irritating? News anchors talking over the first few words of a speech they are about to cover. You know what they could do instead, and very few people would care? Delay the feed of the speech ever so slightly so that we get to hear everything.

subs.text: Sports broadcasts do it all the time, not so much for speeches or news conferences, but for the live events they cover, and it’s so fluid that hardly anybody notices.
subs.rawText: Sports broadcasts do it all the time, not so much for speeches or news conferences, but for the live events they cover, and it’s so fluid that hardly anybody notices.

subs.text: The next time you watch a baseball game on TV, notice how, when the broadcasts show a pitcher up close, they very slightly rewind the action once the pitch is actually made.
subs.rawText: The next time you watch a baseball game on TV, notice how, when the broadcasts show a pitcher up close, they very slightly rewind the action once the pitch is actually made.

subs.text: @BovyMaltz Being a mutual follower of someone, but suspecting that each of us is no longer interested in what the other has to say anymore, is definitely a thing, and we need a social convention for mutually unfollowing without any hard feelings.
subs.rawText: @BovyMaltz Being a mutual follower of someone, but suspecting that each of us is no longer interested in what the other has to say anymore, is definitely a thing, and we need a social convention for mutually unfollowing without any hard feelings.

subs.text: Twitter needs a “This tweet has been dunked on enough already!” warning label.

subs.text: A quick mockup. [link]
subs.rawText: A quick mockup. https://t.co/105d4VLEu8

subs.text: A better mockup would have a basketball hoop icon for the “View current dunks” option.
subs.rawText: A better mockup would have a basketball hoop icon for the “View current dunks” option.

subs.text: A more serious way that Twitter could do it is to alter the Quote Tweet function so that it notes how many quote tweets already exist, and offer people the option to look at them first and just retweet one of those.
subs.rawText: A more serious way that Twitter could do it is to alter the Quote Tweet function so that it notes how many quote tweets already exist, and offer people the option to look at them first and just retweet one of those.

subs.text: I’d follow accounts that are “[X] but without the dunks” much like how @newyorker_nb is the “All the New Yorker, none of the Borowitz.”
subs.rawText: I’d follow accounts that are “[X] but without the dunks” much like how @newyorker_nb is the “All the New Yorker, none of the Borowitz.”

subs.text: Ever since watching Dark City, I can’t stop thinking about this quote from Roger Ebert’s review of the movie: “I realized the last dozen films I’d seen were about people standing around, talking to one another.” [link]
subs.rawText: Ever since watching Dark City, I can’t stop thinking about this quote from Roger Ebert’s review of the movie: “I realized the last dozen films I’d seen were about people standing around, talking to one another.” https://t.co/jZuiVhOfhC

subs.text: Since reading that, I realized that I could stop watching a lot of movies and just listen to them.
subs.rawText: Since reading that, I realized that I could stop watching a lot of movies and just listen to them.

subs.text: This came to mind when watching the interviews in Quintin Smith’s “Making Sense of VRChat” video. Ultimately, watching it was valuable, but there’s so much (virtual) standing around and talking to one another that you can get a lot out of just the audio. [link]
subs.rawText: This came to mind when watching the interviews in Quintin Smith’s “Making Sense of VRChat” video. Ultimately, watching it was valuable, but there’s so much (virtual) standing around and talking to one another that you can get a lot out of just the audio. https://t.co/Cqidjsezdo

subs.text: Maybe, for video, I could use a prompt for the times when I really should watch and for the times when I can get everything from just listening.
subs.rawText: Maybe, for video, I could use a prompt for the times when I really should watch and for the times when I can get everything from just listening.

subs.text: One of the band members has an Aphex Twin sticker on his guitar. That’s how I can tell he’s cool.
subs.rawText: One of the band members has an Aphex Twin sticker on his guitar. That’s how I can tell he’s cool.

subs.text: It’s possible, for fucking once, that I made a friend at a concert. I saw a guy who I was pretty sure came alone (I was right), and invited him to sit with me. He initially declined, but then came over and thanked me and talked to me every now and then throughout the show.
subs.rawText: It’s possible, for fucking once, that I made a friend at a concert. I saw a guy who I was pretty sure came alone (I was right), and invited him to sit with me. He initially declined, but then came over and thanked me and talked to me every now and then throughout the show.

subs.text: That’s a family trait, by the way: We believe we have a sense for people who look like they’d rather not be standing and offer them a seat, but then they politely decline.
subs.rawText: That’s a family trait, by the way: We believe we have a sense for people who look like they’d rather not be standing and offer them a seat, but then they politely decline.

subs.text: If you’re wondering whether @sianspheric killed tonight, well, check out this thread and you tell me. [link]

subs.text: July 1
3 hours of travel time for 15 minutes of fireworks. 🆒
subs.rawText: 3 hours of travel time for 15 minutes of fireworks. 🆒

subs.text: I would have wasted the time anyway.
subs.rawText: I would have wasted the time anyway.

subs.text: Did I mention that I was on the first streetcar out of The Beaches, which was completely full and didn’t move for half an hour during a pandemic of a disease that shreds our lungs and causes permanent brain damage, that we’ll get over and over until it ultimately kills us?
subs.rawText: Did I mention that I was on the first streetcar out of The Beaches, which was completely full and didn’t move for half an hour during a pandemic of a disease that shreds our lungs and causes permanent brain damage, that we’ll get over and over until it ultimately kills us?

subs.text: Tensions were high, as people who hadn’t ridden a streetcar before blocked the doors from closing, but then young women started playing hit pop songs from before the 2000s on their phones and sang along, which seemed to relieve the pressure quite a bit.
subs.rawText: Tensions were high, as people who hadn’t ridden a streetcar before blocked the doors from closing, but then young women started playing hit pop songs from before the 2000s on their phones and sang along, which seemed to relieve the pressure quite a bit.
